channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chávez Heir, Nicolás Maduro, Wins Venezuelan Vote
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked political heir to Hugo Chávez, won election to serve the remainder of Mr. Chávez’s six-year term, officials said late Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: President-elect Nicolás Maduro celebrated with his wife, Cilia Flores, after election results were announced in Caracas.

item.title: In Ríos Montt Trial, Guatemalans Give Account of Suffering
item.description: Many spoke of the horrors they endured as children, when the government was pursuing leftist guerrillas and anyone believed to be sympathizers.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: China’s First-Quarter GDP Growth Slips to 7.7 Percent
item.description: China’s economic recovery unexpectedly stumbled in the first three months of 2013 as the annual rate of growth eased from the 7.9 percent pace set in the final quarter of last year, official data showed on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: New Leak Found at Fukushima Nuclear Plant
item.description: The newest leak will force the operator of the nuclear plant in Japan to postpone the removal of contaminated water for several days.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: WORLD: Venezuela Goes to the Polls
item.description: The Times’s William Neuman reports from Caracas, Venezuela, on the morning of an election for the successor to Hugo Chávez, who died last month.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: A ‘Gangnam Style’ Escape From Korean Tensions
item.description: Psy, the Korean pop sensation and creator of “Gangnam Style,” referred to North Korea during his Seoul concert on Saturday, amid some comic comparisons between him and the North Korean leader and some speculation he could be a peacemaker.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Singer Psy performing his new single "Gentleman" in a concert titled "Happening" at the Olympic Stadium in Seoul.

item.title: Carmen Weinstein, a Leader of Egypt’s Jewish Community, Dies at 82
item.description: Ms. Weinstein was the driving force behind the restoration of Maimonides’s yeshiva and other monuments of Egyptian Jewish history.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Samir W Raafat , via Associated Press

item.title: U.S. Visa Delays Put Safety Out of Afghan Interpreters’ Reach
item.description: Afghans who worked for American forces have found themselves without military protection and facing a backlog for visas that could help give them protection.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sulaiman, a combat interpreter, in Kabul, Afghanistan. An American visa has remained beyond his grasp, despite years of effort.

item.title: Google and Europe Reach Deal on Search Results
item.description: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Majuli Journal: Indian Island Shrinks as Brahmaputra Swells and Sways
item.description: The Brahmaputra River, a critical laboratory in climate studies, is fast eroding an island in Assam that it has encircled and sustained for ages.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Enrico Fabian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man wove bamboo to build a wall for a hut. The Brahmaputra River encircles the island of Majuli, home to about 170,000 people and dozens of monasteries.

item.title: Deadly Attacks Strike Somalia’s Capital, Mogadishu
item.description: Islamists militants known as the Shabab carried out a suicide attack on the court complex, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Mothers ran with their children Sunday after a suicide attack on the court complex in Mogadishu, Somalia. Later, a blast hit an international convoy, officials said.

item.title: Elites Flock to Anti-Euro Party, Alternative for Germany
item.description: Alternative for Germany, started by a Hamburg economics professor, could play the role of spoiler in the September elections.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Members of Alternative for Germany, which held a party congress on Sunday in a Berlin hotel.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Elected Leader of Liberal Party of Canada
item.description: Justin Trudeau, 41, the son of Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who was prime minister for 15 years, is faced with reviving a party that is no longer dominant in federal politics.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Undercover BBC Trip to North Korea Is Criticized
item.description: Reporters who joined students from the London School of Economics on the trip did not disclose their true purpose and filmed an undercover documentary, the university said.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: World Military Spending Dips in 2012, First Since 1998
item.description: Military spending dropped thanks to deep cuts in the United States and Europe that made up for increases in countries like China and Russia, a leading think-tank said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Fayyad’s Resignation Means Uncertainty for Palestinians
item.description: The resignation of the Palestinian Authority’s prime minister, Salam Fayyad, adds a layer of confusion to the already contentious Palestinian political scene.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The Palestinian Authority prime minister, Salam Fayyad, left, and President Mahmoud Abbas.

item.title: Kerry Says Any Talks Rely on Steps by North Korea
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the United States was prepared to reach out if North Korea made the first move to abandon its nuclear weapons program.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived with Japan's Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida at a meeting in Tokyo.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Assad Foes Hire Former British Diplomat to Plead Their Cause
item.description: Syria’s exiled opposition politicians are facing an uphill struggle to get firmer international help in winning the country’s civil war. They’ve taken on a New York-based adviser to help.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Filip Horvat for The New York Times

item.title: Indonesia Warns Aceh Province Over Flag
item.description: The strife-torn Aceh Province passed a bylaw last month that declared the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: New Bird Flu Cases Found in Central China
item.description: Two people in the central Chinese province of Henan have been infected by a new strain of avian influenza, the first cases found in the region, the state news agency said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: China Makes Inroads in Nepal, Stemming Tibetan Presence
item.description: The Chinese are trying to stem the flow of disaffected Tibetans fleeing to Nepal and to enlist the help of the Nepalese in cracking down on the political activities of those already there.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The stupa of a temple in Katmandu.

item.title: Kerry Arrives in China Seeking Help on North Korea
item.description: Amid fears that North Korea is ready to launch a medium-range missile, the United States is trying to enlist China’s assistance in defusing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greeting China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, on Saturday in Beijing.

item.title: Salam Fayyad, Palestinian Prime Minister, Resigns
item.description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad had clashed politically with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Western-backed Palestinian Authority, which governs the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank city of Ramallah in January.

item.title: Sierra Leone Graft Charges Imperil Care and Aid
item.description: The top leadership of the Healthy Ministry faces charges of misusing foreign funds, raising alarm in a nation with the region’s worst health statistics.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Children bathing at a sawmill drainage pipe in Freetown amid a cholera emergency last year. The country has among the worst health statistics in the world and relies heavily on foreign aid.

item.title: Michel Djotodia, Leader of Coup in Central African Republic, Holds On to Power
item.description: Michel Djotodia, a wily opportunist who conducted a coup d’état in the Central African Republic in March, continues to hold the presidency, despite an international outcry.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Michel Djotodia declared himself president of the Central African Republic in a March coup. Governments around the world have refused to recognize him as a legitimate head of state.
